utterance: O, dear me! Cliristmas is a bore! Such a rush and crush in the streets, such a jam in the shops, and then such a fuss thinking up presents for everybody ! All for nothing, too ; for nobody wants anything. I'm sure I don't. I'm surfeited now with pictures and jewelry, and bon-bon boxes, and little china dogs and cats — and all these things that get so thick yon can't move without upsetting some of them. There's papa, he don't want anything. He never uses any of my Christmas presents when I get them ; and mamma, she has every earthly thing I can think of, and said the other day she did hope nobody'd give her anymore worsted work! Then Aunt Maria and Uncle John, they don't want the things I give them ; they have more than they know what to do with, now. AH the boys say they don't want any more cigar cases or slippers, or smoking caps. Oh, dear!
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: I wish I knew how to be better!
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: I remember last Sunday's text, ' It is more blessed to give than to receive.' That must mean something ! Well, isn't there something, too, in the Bible about not giving to your rich neighbors that can give agaiii, but giving to the poor that cannot recompense you ? I don't know any poor people. Papa says there are very few deserving poor people. Well, for the matter of that, there aren't many deserving rich people. I, for example, how much do I deserve to hav© all these nice things? I'm no better than the poor shop-girls that go trudging by in the cold at six o'clock in the morning — ugh I it makes me shiver to think of it. I know if I had to do that J shouldn't be good at all. Well, I'd like to give to poor people, if I knew any.
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: Betty, do you know any poor people I ought to get things for, this Christmas?
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: Poor folks is always plenty, miss.
speaker: Betty

utterance: O yes, of course, beggars; but I mean people that I could do something for besides just give cold vituals or money. I don't know where to hunt them up, and should be afraid to go if I did, O dear ! it's no use. I'll give it up.
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: Why, Miss Florence, that 'ud be too bad, afther bein' that good in yer heart, to let the poor folks alone for fear of goin' to theiD. But ye needn't do that, for, now I think of it, there's John Mor- ley's wife.
speaker: Betty

utterance: What, the gardener father turned off for drinking?
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: The same, miss. Poor boy, he's not so bad, and he's got a wife and two as pretty children as ever you see.
speaker: Betty

utterance: I always liked John, But papa is so strict about some things ! He says he never will keep a man a day if he finds out that he drinks.
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: I don't care ; it's a good idea ! I say, Betty, do you know where John's wife lives ?
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: Yes, miss, I've been there often.
speaker: Betty

utterance: Well, then, this afternoon I'll go with you and see if I can do anything for them.
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: No use to try. Didn't I go a whole year and never touch a drop ? And now just because I fell once I'm kicked out ! No use to try. When a fellow once trips, everybody gives him a kick. Talk about love of Christ I Who believes it ? Don't see much love of Christ where I go. ICour Christians hit a fellow that's do-vy^n as hard as anybody. Ifs everybody for himself and devil take the hindmost. Well, I'll trudge up to the Brooklyn Navy Yard and see if they'll take me on there — if they won't I might as well go to sea, or to the devil
speaker: John Morley

utterance: Mamma, what are we going to have for our Christmas ?
speaker: Elsie

utterance: Sha'n't we have a Christmas, mother ?
speaker: Tottie

utterance: my God, help me.
speaker: John Morley's wife

utterance: Mother, they are dressing the church, and the gates are open, and people are going in and out ; mayn't we play there by the church ?
speaker: Elsie and Tottie

utterance: Yes, my little birds ; you may play there if you'll be very good and quiet.
speaker: John Morley's wife

utterance: Yea, the sparrow hath found a house and the swallow a nest where she may lay her young, even thine altars, Lord of hosts, my king and my God !
speaker: John Morley's wife

utterance: May we play with them, please, sir?
speaker: Elsie

utterance: Oh, yes, to be sure ; these are done with — they are no good now,
speaker: the sexton

utterance: Oh, Tottie ! just think, he says we may play with all these. Why, here's ever and ever so much green, enough to play house. Let's play build a house for father and mother.
speaker: Elsie

utterance: I'm going to build a big house for 'em when I grow up, and I mean to have glass bead windows in it.
speaker: Tottie

utterance: You see we can make believe there are windows and doors and a roof, and it's just as good. Now, let's make believe there is a bed in this corner, and we will lie down to sleep.
speaker: Elsie

utterance: You must play it isn't snow — play it's feathers.
speaker: Elsie

utterance: But I don't like it, it don't feel a bit like feathers.
speaker: Tottie

utterance: Oh, well, then, let's play get up now and I'll get breakfast.
speaker: Elsie

utterance: O Tottie ! O Elsie ! Only see how many pretty things — ^lots and lots I
speaker: Elsie and Tottie

utterance: Don't you want to come in and see the church ? It's all done now, and a brave sight it is. You may come in.
speaker: the sexton

utterance: Hush, Tottie ! don't make a noise. I do be- lieve it's something like heaven,
speaker: Elsie

utterance: You can find lots of pretty Christmas greens out there, perhaps your folks would like to have some.
speaker: the sexton

utterance: Oh, thank you, sir, Oh, Tottie, only think I Let's gather a good lot and go home and dress our room for Christmas. Oh, won't mother be astonished when she comes home, we'll make it so pretty !
speaker: Elsie

utterance: Take heed that ye dispise not these Httle ones, for in heaven their angels —
speaker: the sexton

utterance: It looks pretty when the light comes through,
speaker: Tottie

utterance: Cold as Christmas I
speaker: unnamed speaker

utterance: Its ouy because I was drunk that time that the old man never pardoned me.
speaker: John Morley

utterance:
" I'll pay you full price to-day, but we can't pay such prices any
longer, Hard
times — work dull — we are cutting down all our work-folks ; you'll
have to take a third less next time."
speaker: the man

utterance: " I'll do my best,"
speaker: John Morley's wife

utterance:
" Pm so sorry John lost his place at father's. He was so kind
and obliging, and I always liked him ; and I've been thinking, if
you'd get him to sign the pledge over again from Christmas Eve,
never to touch another drop, I'll get papa to take him back. I
always do get papa to do what I want, and the fact is he hasn't got
anybody that suited him so well since John left. So you tell John
that I mean to go surety for him ; he certainly wont fail me. Tell
him I trust him."
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
"Now, you come with John to-morrow morning, and bring this
with his name to it, and you'll see what I'll do !"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
"Now, papa, I want you to give me something special to-day, be-
cause it's Cln-istmas,"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: "What is it, Pussy — half of my kingdom ?"
speaker: her father

utterance:
"No, no, papa ; not so much as that. It's a little bit of my own
way that I want."
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: "Of course; well, what is it ?"
speaker: her father

utterance: "Well, I want you to take John back again."
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
"Now, please, papa, don't say a word till you have heard me.
John was a capital gardener ; he kept the green-house looking
beautiful ; and this Mike that we've got now, he's nothing but an
apprentice, and stupid as an owl at that ! He'll never do in the
world."
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
" All that is very true, but John drinks, and
I wonH have a drinking man."
speaker: Mr. De Witt

utterance:
" But, plpa, J mean to take care of that. I've written out the
temperance pledge, and dated it, and got John to sign it, and here
it is,"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
" You. ought to have seen how poor, how very poor they were.
His wife is such a nice, quiet, hard-working woman, and has two
such pretty children. I went to see them and carry them Christ-
mas things yesterday, but's no good doing anything if John can't
get work. She told me how the poor fellow had been walking the
streets in the cold, day after day, trying everywhere, and nobody
would take him. It's a dreadful time now for a man to be out of
work, and it isn't fair his poor wife and children should suffer. Do
try him again, papal"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance:
" John always did better with the pineapplas than anybody we
have tried,"
speaker: Mrs. De Witt

utterance:
" He is the only one
who really understands pineapples."
speaker: Mrs. De Witt

utterance: " Please, Miss Florence, the little folks says they wants to give you a Christmas."
speaker: Betty

utterance:
" They thinks much of giving j'^ou something,
poor little things — plaze take it of 'em."
speaker: Betty

utterance:
" We wanted
to give you something,"
speaker: Elsie

utterance:
"Oh, you lovely dears! how sweet of you !
I shall keep these beautiful glass beads always, and put the cross
up over my dressing-table. I thank you ever so much !"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: " Are those John's children ?"
speaker: Mr. De Witt

utterance:
" Yes, papa, see
how sweet they are !"
speaker: Florence DeWitt

utterance: " Well — you may tell John I'll try him again."
speaker: Mr. De Witt

utterance:
"she didn't see nothin' how she was
goin' to get through things — and there was Saphiry's gown, and
Miss Deacon Trowbridge's cloak,*and Lizy Jane's new merino, not
a stroke done on't. The Governor ought to be ashamed of himself
for hurrying matters]^so."
speaker: Miss Briskett

utterance:
"Putty piece o' property, this 'ere farm, None o' yer
stim pastur land where the sheep can t get their noses down through
the rocks without a iile to sharpen 'em ! Deacon Pitkin did a
putty fair stroke o' business when he swapped off his old place for
this 'ere. That are old place was all swamp la
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance:
" Yes, my daughter, you have done wonderfully. We ; couldn't
do without you !"
speaker: Mary Pitkin

utterance: " Well, haven't we done a good day's work cousin ?"
speaker: Diana

utterance:
" Haven't we been
smart?"
speaker: Diana

utterance: 'that are mortgage pinches the deacon ; works him lILo a dose of aloes and picry, it does. Deacon fairly gets lean on't.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: this 'ere place ain't mortgaged, is it.^ Du tell, naow!
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Why, yia; don't ye know that are? Why there's risin' two thousand dollars due on this 'ere farm, and if the deacon don't scratch for it and pay up squar to the minit, old Squire Norcross'U foreclose on him. Old squire hain't no bowels, I tell yen, and the deacon knows he hain't : and I tell you it keeps the deacon dancin' lively as com on a hot shovel.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: The deacon's a master hand to work,
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Wal, yis, the deacon is,
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: She's a good woman, Mis' Pitkin is, and she's a smart worker.
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Smart ain't no word for 't, Declar for 't, the grit o' that are woman beats me. Had eight children right along in a string 'thout stoppin', done all her own work, never kep' no gal nor nothin' ; allers up and dressed ; allers to meetin' Sunday, and to the prayer-meetin' weekly, and never stops workin': when 'tain't one thing it's another — cookin', washin', ironin', making butter and cheese, and 'tween spells cuttin' and sewin', and if she ain't doin' that, why, she's braidin' straw to sell to the store or knitting — she's the perpetual motion ready found. Mis' Pitkin is.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Want ter know, Ain't she smart, though !
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Smart ! Well, I sliould think she was. She's over and into everything that's goin' on in that house. The deacon wouldn't know himself without her ; nor wouldn't none of them boys, they just live out of her ; she kind o' keeps 'em all up.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Wal, she ain't a hefty woman, noaw,
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Law bless you, no ! She's a little crittur ; nothin' to look to, but every bit in her is live. She looks pale, kind o' slips round still like moonshine, but where anything's to be done, there Mis' Pitkin is ; and her hand allers goes to the right spot, and things is done afore you know it. That are woman's kind o' still ; she'll slip off and be gone to heaven some day afore folks know it. There comes the deacon and Jim over the hUl. Jim walked home from college day 'fore yesterday, and turned right in to-day to help get in the taters, workin' right along. Deacon was awful grouty.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: What was the matter o' the deacon ?
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Oh, the mortgage kind o' works him. The time to pay comes round putty soon, and the deacon's face allers goes down long as yer arm. 'Tis a putty tight pull havin' Jim in college, losin' his work and bavin' term bills and things to pay. Them are college {6U<3 charges itp, I tell you. I seen it worka the deacon, I heard him a-jawin' Jim 'bout it.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: What made Jim go to College ?
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: Oh, he allers was sot on eddication, and Mis' Pitkin she's sot on't, too, in her softly way, and softly women is them that giner-'lly carries their p'ints, fust or last.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: But there's one that ainH softly !
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: That crittur has got more prances and capers in her than any three-year old iilly I knows on. He'll be cunning that ever gets a bridle on her.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Seme says she's going to hev Jim Pitkin, and some says it's BiU,
speaker: Abner Jenks

utterance: She's sweet on Jim while he's round, and she's sweet on Bill when Jim's up to college, and between um she gets took round to everything that going. She gives one a word over one shoulder, and one over t'other, and if the Lord above knows what's in that gal's mind or what she's up to, he knows more than I do, or she either, else I lose my bet.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: What in the world ails James?
speaker: Diana

utterance: Oh no, no, my dear,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: we must cast our care on God.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: It's easy for women to talk. You don't have the interest ironey to pay, you are perfectly reckless of expense. Nothing would do but James must go to college, and now see what it's bringing us to !
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Why, father, 1 thought you yourself were in favor of this
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Well, I did wrong then. You persuaded me into it. I had no business to have listened to you and Jim and got all this load on my shoulders.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: But I tell yoTx, father, as God is my witness, I mean to pay all ; you shall not suffer ; interest and principal — all that my work would bring — I engage to pay back.
speaker: James

utterance: You ! — you'll never have anything ! You'll be a poor man as JcTig as you live. Lost the Academy this Fall — that tells the stoy !
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: But, father, it wasn't my fault that I lost the Academy.
speaker: James

utterance: It's no matter whose fault it was — that's neithev here nor there — you lost it, and here you are with the vacation before you and nothing to do ! There's your mother, she's working herself to death ; she never gets any rest. T expect she'll go off in a con- sumption one of these days.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: There, there, Tather ! that's enough! Please don't say any more. You'll see I will find something to do !
speaker: James

utterance: Why, ye work like thunder ! Book I'amin' hain't spiled ye yet ; your arms are good for suthin'.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Yes, my arms are good for something, and I'll use them for something,
speaker: James

utterance: Diana, will you take a walk with me to-night ?
speaker: James

utterance: To-night ! Why, I have just promised Bill to go with him over to the husking at the Jenk's. Why don't you go with us ? We're going to have lots of fun,
speaker: Diana

utterance: T can't. Besides, I wanted to talk with you alone. I had something special I wanted to say.
speaker: James

utterance: Bless me, how you frighten one ! You look solemn as a hearse ; but 1 promised to go with Bill to-night, and I suspect another time will do just as well. What you have to say will keep^ 1 suppose,
speaker: Diana

utterance: I should really like to know what's the matter with you to- night,
speaker: Diana

utterance: He's cross to-night, Well, he'll have to get over his pet. I shan't mind it !
speaker: Diana

utterance: Perhaps she won't care for it, thoughVfcbut if she i^does,*^she is^welcome to it — it may put her in mind of old times.
speaker: James

utterance: There's a chestnut for yon, Mr. Owl, if you will stay moping up there ! Come, now, it's a splendid evening ; won't you come ?
speaker: Diana

utterance: No, thank you. I sha'n't bo missed.
speaker: James

utterance: That's true enough ; the loss is your own. Good bye, Mr, Philosopher.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Good -by, Diana.
speaker: James

utterance: What an awfully solemn voice James has sometimes,
speaker: Diana

utterance: it would make his fortune as a Methodist minister.'*
speaker: Diana

utterance: So much for her.
speaker: James

utterance: Mother, I am done working... I had rather read.
speaker: James

utterance: Well, I am glad to hear it, my son. I am afraid this is drudgery. I'm glad to have the work done for me.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: With all my heart.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Mother, if I ever get into heaven it will be through you.
speaker: James

utterance: Don't say that,my son — it must be through a better friend than I am — who loves you more than I do. I have not died for you — He did.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Oh, that I knew where I might find him, then. You I can see — Him I cannot.
speaker: James

utterance: I feel sure you wlll,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: You are consecrated.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Amen.
speaker: James

utterance: Well, I must not keep you up any longer, mother dear — it's time you were resting. Good night.
speaker: James

utterance: Wal naow — you don't say so,
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Wal, yis, 'tis hard sleddin' for the deacon — drefful hard sleddin'. Wal, naow, s'pose you're disapp'inted — shouldn't wonder — jes' so. Eddi- cation's a good thing, but 'taint the only thing naow ; folks lams a sight rubbin' round the world — and then they make money. Jes' see, there's Cap'n Stebbins and Cap'n Andrews and Cap'n Merry- weather — all livin' on good farms, with good, nice houses, all got goin' to sea. Expect Mis' Pitkin'll take it sort o' hard, she's so sot on you ; but she's allers sayin' things is for the best, and maybe she'll come to think so 'bout this — folks gen'ally does when they can't help themselves. Wal, yis, naow — goin' to walk to the cross- road tavern? better not. Jest wait a minit and I'll hitch up and take ye over.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Thank you, Biah, but I can't stop, and I'd rather walk, so I won't trouble you.
speaker: James

utterance: Wal, look here — don't ye want a sort o' nest-egg? I've got fifty silver dollars laid up : you take it on venture and give me half what it brings.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Thank you, Biah. If you'll trust me with it I'll hope to do something for us both.
speaker: James

utterance: Wanted to go to sea confoundedly myself, but there's Mariar Jane — she won't hear on't, and turns on the water-works if I peep a single word. Farmin's drefful slow, bu' when a feller's got a gal he's got a cap'n ; he has to mind orders. So you jes trade and we'll go sheers. I think consid'able of you, and I expect you'll make it go as fur as anybody.
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: I'll try my best, you may believe, Biah.
speaker: James

utterance: Well, mother !
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Well, father,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: all we can do now is to leave it.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Dear father,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: don't worry about it now ; you didn't mean it. James is a good boy, and he'll see it right at last ; and he is in God's hands, and we must leave him there. He overrules all.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Oh, cousin ! cousin ! Is this true ? Is James gone ? Can't we do any thing ? Can't we get him back ? I've been thinking it over. Oh, if the ship wouldn't sail 1 and I'd go to Salem and beg him to come back, on my knees. Oh, if I had only known yesterday ! Oh, cousin, cousin ! he wanted to talk with me, and I wouldn't hear him ! — oh, if I only had, I could have persuaded him out of it ! Oh, why didn't I know ?
speaker: Diana

utterance: There, there, dear child ! We must accept it just as it is. now that it is done. Don't feel so. We must try to look at the good.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Oh, show me that letter,
speaker: Diana

utterance: He thinks I don't care for him,
speaker: Diana

utterance: Well, I don't wonder ! But I do care ! I love him better than anybody or anything under the sun, and I never will forget him ; he's a brave, noble, good man, and V shall love him as long as I live — I don't care who knows it ! Give me that locket, cousin, and write to him that I shall wear it to my grave.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Dear child, there is no writing to him.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Oh, dear ! that's the worst. Oh, that horrid, horrid sea! It's Hke death — you don't know where they are, and you can't hear from them — and a four years' voyage ! Oh, dear ! oh, dear !
speaker: Diana

utterance: Don't, dear child, don't; you distress me.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Yes, that's just like me,
speaker: Diana

utterance: Here I am thinking only of myself, and you that have had your heart broken are trying to comfort me, and trying to comfort Cousin Silas. We have both of us scolded and flouted him away, and now you, who suffer the most of either of us, spend your breath to com- for us. It's just like you. But, cousin, I'll try to be good and comfort you. I'll try to be a daughter to you. You need some- body to think of you, for you never think of yourself. Let's go in his room,
speaker: Diana

utterance: It seems like a death,
speaker: Diana

utterance: Don't you think the ocean is like death — wide, dark, storiry, unknown ? We cannot speak to or hear from them that are on it.
speaker: Diana

utterance: But people can and do come back from the sea'
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: I trust, in God's own time, we shall see James back.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: But what if we never should? Oh, cousin ! I can't help think- ing of that. There was Michael Davis, — you know — the ship was never heard from.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Wife,
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: read me something I can't quite remember out of the Bible. It's in the eighth of Deuteronomy, the second verse.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: There, that's it,
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: That's what I've been thinking of as I've lain here sick and helpless. I've fought hard to keep things stra^ht and clear the farm, but it's pleased the Lord to bring me low. I've had to lie still and leave all in His hands.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: And where better could you leave all ?
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Well, just so. I've been saying, 'Here I am. Lord ; do with me as seemeth to thee good,' and I feel a great quiet now. I think it's doubtful if we make up the interest this year. I don't know what Bill may get for the hay : but I don't see much prospect of raisin' on't ; and yet I don't worry. Even if it's the Lord's will to have the place sold up and we be turned out in our old age, 1 don't seem to worry about it. His will be done.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Here I come for Thanksgiving,
speaker: Diana

utterance: and here, here's the interest money for this year. I got it all myself, because I Wi^ ated to show you I could be good for something.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Thank you, dear daughter,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: T felt sure some way would be found, and now I see tvhat.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: a very pleasant, pretty way it is, too.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: I was afraid that Uncle Silas would worry and put himself back again about the interest money,
speaker: Diana

utterance: Well, daughter,
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: it's a pity we should go through all we do in this world and not learn anything by it. I hope the Lord has taught me not to worry, but just do my best and leave myself and everything else in his hands. We can't help ourselves ; we can't make one hair white or black. Why should we wear out our lives out fretting ? If I'd a known tJiat years ago it would a' been better for us all.
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Never mind, father, you know it now,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Well now,
speaker: Diana

utterance: I should like to know what Biah Carter is coming here about.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Oh, Biah's been very kind tons in this sickne&s,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Good evenin', Deacon,
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Good evenin', Mrs. Pitkin. Sarvant, ma'am, to Diana — how ye all geitin' <m ?
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Nicel}', Biah — well as can be,
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Wal, you see I was up to the store with some o* Squire Jones's bell flowers. Sim Goan he said he wanted some to sell, and so I took v-p a couple o' barrels, and I see the damdest big letter there for the Deacon. Miss Briskett she was in, lookin' at it, and so was Deacon Simpson's wife ; she come in orter some cinnamon sticks. Wal, and they all looked at ii and talked it over, and couldn't, none o' 'em for their lives think what it's ail about, it was sich an almighty thick letter,
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: T hope there isn't bad news in it,
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Why, mother, do look ! Is this so ? Do I read it right ?
speaker: Silas Pitkin

utterance: Certainly, you do,
speaker: Diana

utterance: Somebody's paid that debt, uncle!
speaker: Diana

utterance: Thank God !
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: He has done it.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Wall, I swow !
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: if this 'ere don't beat alll There's old Squire Norcross's name on't. It's the receipt, full and square. What's come ovci* the old crittur ? He mus
speaker: Biah Carter

utterance: Mother, don't you know me ?
speaker: a dark stranger

utterance: O my son, my son !
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: What, cousin ! no welcome from you?
speaker: James

utterance: I say, boys, who'll help bring in my sea chest?
speaker: James

utterance: There, mother, I'm determined you shall have a dress fit for you ; and here's a real India shawl to go with it. Get those on and you'll look as much like a queen among women as you ought to.
speaker: James

utterance: Oh, what's that ?
speaker: Ssm

utterance: That's— oh — that's my wife's wedding-dress, and here's her shawl,
speaker: James

utterance: All right, my daughter — just right.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Well, your father mustn't be kept up too late. Let's have prayers now, and then to-morrow we'll be fresh to talk more.
speaker: Mrs. Pitkin

utterance: Father, let me read my Psalm ; it has been my Psalm ever since I left you.
speaker: James

utterance: And now, it's seven years since I left you, and to-morrow is the seventh Thanksgiving, and I've always set my heart on getting home to be married Thanksgiving evening.
speaker: James

utterance: But, dear me, Jim, we can't. There isn't time.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Why not? — we've got all the time there is !
speaker: James

utterance: But the wedding-dress can't be made, possibly.*
speaker: Diana

utterance: Oh, that can wait till the week after. You are pretty enough without it I
speaker: James

utterance: But what will they all say ?
speaker: Diana

utterance: Who cares what they say ? I don't, The fact is, I've set my heart on it, and you owe me something for the way you treated me the last Thanksgiving I was here, seven years ago. Now don't you ?
speaker: James

utterance: Well, yes, I do, so have it just as you will.
speaker: Diana

utterance: Well, Master Jones, here we are,'*
speaker: Elder Brewster

utterance: Aye, aye, sir, here we be sure enough ; but I've had many a shrewd doubt of this upshot. I tell you, sirs, when that beam amidships sprung and cracked Master Coppin here said we must give over — hands couldn't bring her through. Thou rememberest, Master Coppin ?
speaker: Master Jones

utterance: That I do, I said then that praying might save her, perhaps, but nothing else would.
speaker: Master Coppin

utterance: Praying wouldn't have saved her,if I had not put in that screw and worked the beam to her place again.
speaker: Master Brown

utterance: Aye, aye, Master Carpenter, the Lord hftth abundance of the needful ever to his hand. When He wills to answer prayer, there will be found both carpenter and screws in their season, I trow.
speaker: Elder Brewster

utterance: Well, Deb, what sayest thou ? Give us thy mind on it, old girl; say, wilt thou go deer-hunting with us yonder ?
speaker: Master Coppin

utterance: Well done, Why, here is a salute of ordnance! Old Deb is in the spirit of the thing and opens out like a cannon. The old girl is spoiling for a chase in those woods.
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: Father, may I go ashore? 1 want to see the country,
speaker: Wrestling Brewster

utterance: Oh, mother, mother, ask that we may all go ashore.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: For my part, I want to go ashore to wash and be decent, for there isn't a soul of ns hath anything fit for Christians. Y. ere be springs of water, I trow.
speaker: Margery

utterance: Never doubt it my woman, but all things in their order. How say you, Mr. Carver 'i You are our governor. What order shall we take ?
speaker: Elder Brewster

utterance: We must have np the shallop, and send a picked company to see what entertainment there may be for us on shore.
speaker: Mr. Carver

utterance: And I counsel that all go well armed, for these men of the forest are sharper than a thorn-hedge. What ! what ! ye would go ashore would ye? Why, the lions and bears will make one mouthful of ye.
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: I'm not afraid of lions, I'd like to meet a lion, and serve him as Samson did. I'd get honey out of him, I promise.
speaker: Wrestling Brewster

utterance: Oh, there you are, young Master Boastful ! Mind the old saying, 'Brag is a good dog, but holdfast is better.'
speaker: Margery

utterance: Dear husband, wilt thou go ashore in this company ?
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Why, aye, sweetheart, what else am I come for— and who should go if not II
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: Thou art so very venturesome, Miles.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Even so, my Rose of the Wilderness. Why else am I come on this quest ? Not being gOv>d enough to be in your church nor one of the saints, I come for an arm of flesh to them, and so, here goes on my armour.
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: Come hither, dear old Deb, thou must not take on so ; thy master jwill be back again ; so be a good dog now, and lie down.
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: See the darling, what a way that baby hatu ! In all the roughness and the terrors of the sea she hath been like a little sunbeam to us — yet she is so frail !
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: She hath been marked in the womb by the troubles her mother bore, She never had the ways of other babies, but hath ever that wistful look — and her eyes are brighter than they should be. Mistress Winslow will nev- er raise that child — now mark me !'
speaker: Margery

utterance: Take care ! let not her mother hear you.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Why, look at her beside of Wrestling Brewster, or Faith Carver. They are flesh and blood, and she looks as if she had been made out of sunshine. 'Tis a sweet babe as ever was ; but fitter for the kingdom of heaven than our rough life — deary me ! 'a hard time we have had of it. I suppose it's all best, but I don't know.
speaker: Margery

utterance: Oh, never talk that way, Margery, we must all keep up heart, our own and one another's.'*
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Ah, well-a-day ! I suppose so ; but then I look at my good Master Brewster and remember how, when I was a girl, he was at our good Queen Elizabeth's court, ruffling it with the best, and everybody said that there wasn't a young man that had good for- tune to equal his. Why, Master Davidson, the Queen's Secretary of State, thought all the world of him ; and when he went to Hol- land on the Queen's business, he must take him along ; and when he took the keys of the cities there, it was my master that he trusted them to, who used to sleep with them under his pillow. I remember when he cq,me home to the Queen's ..ourt, wearing the
speaker: Margery

utterance: Well, good Margery, it isn't the coat but the heart under it — that's the thing. Thou hast more cause of pride in thy master's poverty than in his riches.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: May be so— I don't know, but he hath had many a sore trouble in worldly things — driven and hunted from place to place in England, clapt into prison, and all he had eaten up with fines and charges and costs.
speaker: Margery

utterance: All that is because he chose rather to suffer affliction with the people of God than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season, he shall have his reward by-and-by.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Well, there be good men and godly in Old England that get to heaven in better coats and with easy carriages and fine houses and servants, and I would my master had been of such. But if he must come to the wilderness 1 will come with him. Gracious me ! what noise is that ?
speaker: Margery

utterance: I do believe there is that Frank Billington at the gunpowder ; that boy will never leave, I do be- lieve, till he hath blown up the ship's company.
speaker: Margery

utterance: Look here now, Master Mtalapert, see what you'll get when your father comes home ! Lord a mercy ! here was half a keg of powder standing open ! Enough to have blown us al? up ! Here, Master Clarke, Master Clarke, come and keep this boy with you till his father come back, or we be all sent sky high before we know.
speaker: Margery

utterance: See there, what fine red berries Captain Miles Standish hath brought.
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: Yea, my little maid, there is a brave lot of holly berries for thee to dress the cabin v/itlial. We shall not want for Christmas greens here, though the houses and churches are yet to come.
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: Yea, Brother Miles, the trees of the Lord are full of sap m this land, even the cedars of Lebanon, which he hath planted. It hath the look to me of a land which the Lord our God hath blessed.
speaker: Elder Brewster

utterance: There is a most excellent depth of black, rich earth, and a great tangle of grapevines, whereon the leaves in many places yet hung, and we picked up stores of walnuts under a tree — not so big as our English ones — but sweet and well-flavored.
speaker: Mr. Carver

utterance: Know ye, bretiicxn, what in this land sniejleth sweetest to me? It is the smell of liberty. The soil is free — no man hath claim thereon. In Old England a poor man may starve right on his mother's bosom ; there may be stores of fish in the river, and bird and fow
speaker: Elder Brewster

utterance: Amen, brother!
speaker: Miles Standish

utterance: Fear no more the frown of the great, Thou art past the tyrant's stroke ; Care no more to clothe and eat. To thee the reed is as the oak.
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: There goes a great tree on shore !
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: Dost hear, mother? I've been count- ing the strokes — fifteen — and then crackle ! crackle I crackle ! and down it comes !
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: Peace, darhng, hear what old Margery is singing below :
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: Why do you cry, mother ?
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: I was thinking of dear Auntie, who is gone from us.
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: She is not gone from us, mother.
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: My darling, she is with Jesus.
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: Well, mother, Jesus is ever with us — you tell me that — and if she is with him she is with us too — I know she is — for sometimes I see her. She sat by me last night and stroked my head when that ugly stormy wind waked me — she looked so sweet, oh, ever so beautiful I — and she made me go to sleep so quiet — it is sweet to be as she is, mother — not away from us but with Jesus.
speaker: Love Winslow

utterance: These little ones see further in the kingdom than we. If we would be like them we should take things easier. When the Lord would show who was greatest in His king- dom, he took a little child on his lap.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Ah me, Rose ! I am aweary in spirit with this tossing sea-life. I long to have a home on dry land once more, be it ever so poor. The sea wearies me. Only think, it is almost Christmas time, only two days now to Christmas. How shall we keep it in these woods ?
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: Aye, aye, a hrave miustor and to do is there now in old England ; and men and boys going foi-th singing and bearing home branches of holly, and pine, and mistletoe for Christmas greens. Oh ! I remember I used to go forth with them and help-dress the churches. God help the poor children, they will grow up in the wilderness and never see such brave sights as I have. They will ne know what a church is, such as they are in old England, with fine old windows like the clouds, and rainbows, and great wonderful arches like the very skies above us, and the brave music with the old organs rolling and the boys marching in white garments and singing so as should draw the very heart out of one. All this we have left behind in old England — ah ! well a day ! well a day!
speaker: Margery

utterance: Oh, but, Margery, we have a * better country' than old England, where the saints and angels are keep- ing Christmas ; we confess that we are strangers and pilgrims on earth.
speaker: Mary Winslow

utterance: For they that say such things declare plainly that they seek a coun- try. For if they had been mindful of that country from whence l^ey canie out they had leisure to have returned. Bu* now they desire a better — that is, an heavenly ; wherefore God is not ashamed of them to be called their God.
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Come hither, pretty one, and Rose will sing thee a brave carol for Christmas. We won't bo dovmhearted, will we ? Hark now to what the minstrels used to sing under my window when I was a little girl :
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Now, isn't that a brave ballad ?
speaker: Rose Standish

utterance: Yea, and thou singest like a real English robin, to do the heart good to hear thee.
speaker: Margery

utterance: Come, bring with a noise, My merry boys. The Christmas log to the firing ; While my good dame, she Bids ye all be free, And drink to your hearts' desiring. Drink now the strong beer, Cut the white loaf here. The while tlie meat is shredding For the rare minced pie, And the plums stand by To fill the paste that's a-kneading.
speaker: Master Coppin

utterance: Ah, well-a day, Master Jones, it is dull cheer to sing Christmas songs here in the woods, with only the owls and the bears for choristers. I wish I could hear the bells of merry England once more
speaker: Master Coppin

utterance: See here, when my Rose singeth, the children gatb«)r round her like bees round a flower. Come, let US all strike up a goodly carol together. Sing one, sing all, girls and boys, and get a bit of Old England's Christmas before to-mor- row, when wo must to our work on shore.
speaker: Captain Miles Standish

utterance: What do these weak Jews ? If a fox j;o up, he shall break down their stone wall ; yet the Lord our God is with us, and He can cause our work to prosper.
speaker: Sanballat the Horonite, Tobias the Ammonite, and Geshem the Arabian
